Act2Scene2.speaker: Lady Macbeth
Act2Scene2.text: That which hath made them drunk hath made me bold. What hath quenched them hath given me fire. Hark!—Peace. The doors are open, and the surfeited grooms Do mock their charge with snores. I have drugged their possets,

Act2Scene2.speaker: Lady Macbeth
Act2Scene2.text: Alack, I am afraid they have awaked, And ’tis not done. Th’ attempt and not the deed Confounds us. Hark!—I laid their daggers ready; He could not miss ’em. Had he not resembled My father as he slept, I had done ’t. My husband?

Act2Scene2.speaker: Macbeth
Act2Scene2.text: I have done the deed. Didst thou not hear a noise?

Act2Scene2.speaker: Lady Macbeth
Act2Scene2.text: I heard the owl scream and the crickets cry.

Act2Scene2.speaker: Lady Macbeth
Act2Scene2.text: A foolish thought, to say a sorry sight.

Act2Scene2.speaker: Macbeth
Act2Scene2.text: There’s one did laugh in ’s sleep, and one cried “Murder!” That they did wake each other. I stood and heard them. But they did say their prayers and addressed them Again to sleep.

Act2Scene2.speaker: Lady Macbeth
Act2Scene2.text: Go get some water And wash this filthy witness from your hand.— Why did you bring these daggers from the place? They must lie there. Go, carry them and smear The sleepy grooms with blood.

Act2Scene2.speaker: Macbeth
Act2Scene2.text: I’ll go no more. I am afraid to think what I have done. Look on ’t again I dare not.

Act2Scene2.speaker: Lady Macbeth
Act2Scene2.text: Infirm of purpose! Give me the daggers. If he do bleed, I’ll gild the faces of the grooms withal, For it must seem their guilt.

Act2Scene2.speaker: Macbeth
Act2Scene2.text: Whence is that knocking? How is ’t with me when every noise appalls me? What hands are here! Ha, they pluck out mine eyes. Will all great Neptune’s ocean wash this blood Clean from my hand?

Act2Scene2.speaker: Lady Macbeth
Act2Scene2.text: My hands are of your color, but I shame To wear a heart so white. I hear a knocking At the south entry. Retire we to our chamber. A little water clears us of this deed. How easy is it, then! Your constancy Hath left you unattended. Hark, more knocking. Get on your nightgown, lest occasion call us And show us to be watchers. Be not lost So poorly in your thoughts.

Act2Scene2.speaker: Macbeth
Act2Scene2.text: To know my deed ’twere best not know myself. Wake Duncan with thy knocking. I would thou Couldst.
